i’m interested in making an FMS-like setup for home use, essentially the network part of FMS without the scoring, buttons, etc, so that our “practice” network setup is as similar to “comp” setup as possible.

does anyone have any advice for that? we could use Cheesy Arena Lite, I think, maybe running on some small dedicated thing (pi? NUC?), with some switches for enablement. i’d like to avoid a VLAN-capable switch if i could avoid it. any advice on AP’s? use the 109/113? some linksys thing? something else?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":36,"updated_at":"2024-11-25T04:44:03.161Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":191,"reads":646,"readers_count":645,"score":1079.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":475559,"topic_slug":"home-fms","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/vh-109-access-point-for-multiple-robots/474978/9","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"VH-109 Access Point for Multiple Robots?","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/home-fms/475559/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3451544,"name":"Thad House","username":"Thad_House","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/a4c791/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-11-25T04:58:43.834Z","cooked":"

It kind of depends on how far you want to go. You realistically have 3 options.

  1. Just run a VH-109 with normal firmware but set to AP mode, and another VH-109 on the robot. This won’t require a VLAN switch. This will give you the same radio setup as the field, in addition to the same control paths (Note the FMS never talks to the robot directly. It only talks to the DS). This configuration will have neither the bandwidth limits or the firewalls enabled (Due to VH not giving us the ability to configure these.)
  2. Use a VH-109 with the Practice mode firmware. This will require a VLAN switch, but does not require an FMS. This will gain you the Bandwidth limit (as iirc that FW has the bandwidth enabled), but still won’t gain you the firewall. You can use a cheap VLAN switch for this, I’ve used a TL-SG108E for this, it works well.
  3. Use a VH-109 with the Offseason FW. This will both require a VLAN switch and an FMS setup (This also requires either a DHCP enabled switch, or DHCP servers running on each VLAN on the FMS). Something like Cheesy Arena works for this, I’m not sure if Cheesy Arena Lite has been updated to support the VH radio. This setup will enable both the BW limit and the firewall. Due to the firewall, and the firewall matching the field configuration, having an FMS will be required for any connection, as on field setups the DS is unable to connect to the robot without also being connected to the FMS.

Realistically, the Firewall doesn’t actually change much. So the best recommendation for getting as close to the network setup on the real field is Option 2. That gets you the BW limit, and still enables hooking up an FMS if you want, but its not a hard requirement, unlike option 3. The communication paths are basically identical here as on the real field.

truher:

is the FMS itself involved in the DS heartbeat disconnect logic? or does the FMS somehow add latency that would reduce the effective heartbeat latency margin?

The FMS isn’t involved with Robot communication at all. It knows nothing about the robot, and no robot communication traffic flows through the FMS software itself. Any extra latency would be caused by the network, which option 2 would be basically an exact match, except for the switches used. But if a switch was adding that much latency, every team would be seeing that.

For radio FW, theres an offseason and a practice firmware listed on the firmware page, with some more docs on what those mean.

I’m trying to setup the VH-109 Full Field option without an FMS, which corresponds to option #2. The goal is to have two robots each connected with to their own driver station. Unfortunately for my team, my networking knowledge stops short of VLANs and managed switches. Reading through this thread and the vh-109 to vh-113- conversion thread, I attempted to get this configured, but I have not yet been successful. In terms of firmware, I have VH-109_AP_PRACTICE_1.2.6-11102024 installed on the access point and VH-109_1.2.6-11102024 installed on the radio on the robot. I’m using a TL-SG108E as the managed switch.

Physical configuration:

Port 1: VH-109 access point
Port 2: laptop to configure switch
Port 3: driver station laptop to connect to FRC-3061-A SSID via VLAN 40 (Blue1)
Port 4: programming laptop to connect to FRC-3061-A SSID via VLAN 40 (Blue1)
Port 5: driver station laptop to connect to FRC-3061-P SSID via VLAN 50 (Blue2)

Port 7:

Current Status

  1. The VH-109 access point has an IP address of 192.168.69.1.
  2. The TL-SG108E has an IP address of 192.168.69.187 assigned via DHCP
  3. The laptop in port 2 is assigned an IP address within 192.168.69.z via DHCP
  4. The VH-109 access point doesn’t connect to the VH-109 radio on the robot. This seems like a critical step. Honestly, I expected that this part would “just work.” The only odd configuration related to this is use of the SSID suffix. Thoughts on where I went wrong would be greatly appreciated.

Questions

I have so many questions; I appreciate any answers that the community can provide:

  1. Since we aren’t running an FMS, does blue vs. red matter from a VLAN perspective? Won’t the individual driver stations set their alliance station since it won’t be assigned by an FMS?

  2. There is a DHCP server on the VH-109 access point. It assigns address within 192.168.69.x. What is the expected IP of the driver station laptop connected to port 3? That laptop currently has a static IP set to 10.30.61.5 and other settings per the WPILib documentation recommendations. I’m not sure how the driver station laptop will find the access point since the VH-109 access point doesn’t have an IP of 10.30.61.4 (or is it listening on that addresses as well?). From reading the threads, it seems like the 10.xx.yy IP values should still be correct. When I connect the programming laptop to port 4, it gets an IP address in the 192.168.69.x range; not the 10.30.61.x range; so, it won’t be able to see the robot. I think if I understood how this aspect is suppose to work, I could make a lot more progress. Alternatively, I can conceptualize that the VH-109 access point would connect the driver station laptop to the devices on the robot, including the robot radio and its DHCP server. So, the driver station laptop could get an IP from the robot’s radio. However, I also read that the VH-109 access point has a DHCP server on each VLAN. Wouldn’t two DHCP servers on the same VLAN cause issues?

  3. Should ports 3, 4, 5 not be part of VLAN 1? I left them on VLAN 1 based on an example I saw in the TL-SG108E documentation.

  4. Does port 1 on the TL-SG108E have to be configured as tagged so that the VH-109 access point can distinguish between the different VLANs? My guess is that it does so that it can route packets from different VLANs over the different wireless connections. I didn’t try this since I wasn’t sure if the VH-109 access point can handle VLAN info in the frames.

  5. Do I really need to configure the 802.1Q PVID settings? If so, did I do it correctly? I really don’t understand the purpose of those settings beyond what I have already configured in terms of 802.1Q VLAN settings.

  6. The VH-109 radio allows an SSID suffix up to 8 characters. However the VH-109 access point doesn’t support a 17 character SSID. With “FRC-3061-” prepended, an 8 character suffix exceeds this limit. So, I changed the suffix to a single letter to work around this error. Is this an inconsistency or a misunderstanding on my part?

  7. When I reboot the VH-109 access point, it appears to lose its configuration and I have to enter the SSID and WPA keys again for Blue 1 and Blue 2. Is this expected?

  8. On the TL-5G108E, IGMP Snooping is enabled by default. Should this be disabled?

@Thad_House , you mentioned that you had success with this switch. Perhaps you could share more details about your specific configuration.

When I get this working, I’ll document it and share it on our team’s OA thread. I expect that most teams that run two robots will want to implement an approach like this.

I’ll answer more when I get home, but that vlan configuration doesn’t look quite right. Each vlan needs to have both tagged and untagged ports. I just don’t remember if the ap needs to be on the untagged ports or the tagged ports. I’ll look at my configuration when I get home.

Also, the robot radio is just looking for TEAM as the ssid, not FRC-TEAM. That is likely why the radios are not connecting.

For some of the other questions. Which vlan is which ds doesn’t really matter without an fms. The critical part is that each robot is on separate vlans and its vlan matches across the whole path. Also yes, every ap reboot the settings get lost. I wish this wasn’t the case, and maybe in the future we can get a firmware update that allows saving those across boots.

You did an amazing job at explaining

gcschmit:

Since we aren’t running an FMS, does blue vs. red matter from a VLAN perspective? Won’t the individual driver stations set their alliance station since an FMS won’t assign it?

You must set the VLANs as described in the radio documentation (10,20,30,40,50,60), but it doesn’t matter to which port you are connected. (eg. you set port 3 to VLAN 10, and connect a DS to this port, your DS will automatically be set to RED 1 (can be seen in Driver Station)).

gcschmit:

There is a DHCP server on the VH-109 access point. It assigns address within 192.168.69.x. What is the expected IP of the driver station laptop connected to port 3? That laptop currently has a static IP set to 10.30.61.5 and other settings per the WPILib documentation recommendations. I’m not sure how the driver station laptop will find the access point since the VH-109 access point doesn’t have an IP of 10.30.61.4 (or is it listening on that addresses as well?). From reading the threads, it seems like the 10.xx.yy IP values should still be correct. When I connect the programming laptop to port 4, it gets an IP address in the 192.168.69.x range; not the 10.30.61.x range; so, it won’t be able to see the robot. I think if I understood how this aspect is suppose to work, I could make a lot more progress. Alternatively, I can conceptualize that the VH-109 access point would connect the driver station laptop to the devices on the robot, including the robot radio and its DHCP server. So, the driver station laptop could get an IP from the robot’s radio. However, I also read that the VH-109 access point has a DHCP server on each VLAN. Wouldn’t two DHCP servers on the same VLAN cause issues?

What happened here is that the switch was giving the IP addresses, not the radio. The IP of the AP radio should be 10.0.100.2.
The IP 192.168.69.1 is the “failsafe/management IP address”.

gcschmit:

Should ports 3, 4, 5 not be part of VLAN 1? I left them on VLAN 1 based on an example I saw in the TL-SG108E documentation.

This is the configuration I used (ignore the CA), You can change the ports’ number as you wish:

gcschmit:

The VH-109 radio allows an SSID suffix up to 8 characters. However the VH-109 access point doesn’t support a 17 character SSID. With “FRC-3061-” prepended, an 8 character suffix exceeds this limit. So, I changed the suffix to a single letter to work around this error. Is this an inconsistency or a misunderstanding on my part?

I believe you have a slight mistake. The “prepended” suffix is just your team number (from the last time I checked), you can check it very easily by connecting to your robot’s radio and open 192.168.69.1/status
One of the line will say something like “radio name”.

gcschmit:

When I reboot the VH-109 access point, it appears to lose its configuration and I have to enter the SSID and WPA keys again for Blue 1 and Blue 2. Is this expected?

It happened to me, too, and I believe it’s an expected thing. (I hope I’m wrong, but I didn’t see any documentation or CD post about it)
It’s not that bad, you need to do it once a day, and it takes 2 minutes.

I will throw some questions back to you:

  1. please do arp -a when you connect to the switch (on your managing port, seems to be port 2) and please do arp -a when you are connected as a DS. (It will show us which IP your computer can “see”)
  2. I would suggest try changing this
gcschmit:

static IP: 10.30.61.5
gateway: blank
subnet mask: 255.0.0.0

To static IP: 10.30.61.5 with a subnet of 255.255.255.0 with a gateway of 10.30.61.5

  1. try pinging 10.30.61.4 from your DS with this command:
    ping 10.30.61.4
    and see if it works

Thanks to @Thad_House, @DavidMasin, and @kiettyyyy, everything is now working. I’ll clarify a few things that may be of use to others who find this thread until I can type up a more complete document to share.

My 802.1Q VLAN settings are now almost the same as @Thad_House (other than assigning ports 3-8 to different VLANs). I did configure port 1 to be tagged on VLANs 10, 20, 40, 50. (If you are using 30 and 60, it needs to be tagged on those as well.) The one change I had to make was I did not configure port 2 to be tagged at all. When I tried doing so, my laptop was unable to connect to anything. Perhaps it doesn’t handle VLAN info in the frame.

802.1Q VLAN settings screenshot

CleanShot 2024-12-11 at 09.19.04@2x1436×1270 97.3 KB

I was definitely thrown by seeing the “FRC-” prefix in the SSID and assumed I would need to specify that on the access point. Once I removed the “FRC-” part, the access point was able to connect to the robot radio.

Thad_House:

I’m assuming the DHCP address for each VLAN are assigned based on the team number that is entered. What is the behavior if an SSID suffix is used? Does the AP still properly parse that team number, and assign that as the address base for that VLAN? Also, it seems slightly weird this is assigning IP .254 to my DS. I would expect it to be assigning .20ish, because that seems to be the IP range for the team firmware in AP mode.

It appears that the AP properly parses the team number when a suffix is specified and properly assign IP addresses. In terms of IP address assignment, my experience was similar in that the computer was assigned an IP of 10.30.61.246.

I did update the network configuration of the driver station:

static IP: 10.30.61.5
gateway: 10.30.61.4
subnet mask: 255.255.255.0

Thad_House:

That’s the behavior of the offseason firmware, not the practice firmware. In the practice firmware, the radio is the dhcp server. The switch being used has no dhcp at all. And it looks like it uses the management subnet for the non vlan network. Which makes sense to me.

I can confirm that the access point is the DHCP server. When connected to port 2, in my configuration, the DHCP server is reported as 192.168.69.1, which is the access point. When connected to port 4, in my configuration, the DHCP server is reported as 10.30.61.4, which the access point. The robot radio at 10.30.61.1 is reachable, but it is not acting as the DHCP server to devices connected to the switch. I should have checked if it is acting as the DHCP server to devices connected to the robot radio. (I’ll try that later.) I’m not sure how the access point and robot radio negotiates this, but it appears to be working.

gcschmit:

DHCP server is reported as 10.30.61.4, which the access point. The robot radio at 10.30.61.1 is reachable, but it is not acting as the DHCP server to devices connected to the switch. I should have checked if it is acting as the DHCP server to devices connected to the robot radio.

This is the expected behavior. The robot radio runs its own dhcp server for the device connected to the robot, and the field radio runs dhcp for the devices hooked up to the field radio. DHCP is never passed over the WiFi connection. It’s this same way on the real field as well.

gcschmit:

The one change I had to make was I did not configure port 2 to be tagged at all. When I tried doing so, my laptop was unable to connect to anything. Perhaps it doesn’t handle VLAN info in the frame.

Are you expecting the device on port 2 to be able to talk to the robots? The way mine was configured, that’s not possible. The only thing it could talk to was the ap. The laptop will likely drop any tagged frames, so only the untagged frames to the ap would get through.

Having port 2 be an untagged port for all the vlans seems like it might cause issues. I’m not sure what the switch behavior for that will be.

Thad_House:

Are you expecting the device on port 2 to be able to talk to the robots? The way mine was configured, that’s not possible. The only thing it could talk to was the ap. The laptop will likely drop any tagged frames, so only the untagged frames to the ap would get through.

I’m not expecting the device on port 2 to talk to the robots; only the AP and the switch configuration interface. Now that the switch is configured, that port is really just to update the AP each boot so that it can connect to the robot radios.

I changed the switch configuration such that port 2 is only on VLAN 1 and is untagged. I also decided to configure 2 ports for each of the 3 blue alliance driver stations. Each driver station can change to the red alliance on their own as need to test that side of the field. Everything seems to be working well.

Thad_House:

What is the behavior if an SSID suffix is used? Does the AP still properly parse that team number, and assign that as the address base for that VLAN?

I just ran into the SSID Suffix question myself.

During my bench testing (Switch / AP / Random laptop (No Robots or DS)

I found if I set all SSIDs to the same number with different Suffix, all laptops get IP’s in the same IP range. (So VLANs 10,20,30 is getting 10.TE.AM.x)

Is this going to be a problem if I have a robot on Red-1 and Red-2, and driver stations on Red-1 and Red-2?

Conceptually, since the robot and DS are in the same VLAN, they shouldn’t hit the default gateway, and they will never be aware of other devices in the different VLANs with the same IP’s.

Just looking for confirmation as I write up our setup directions.
